scraped_itos.title: Gambia Birding Tours - Birding Ecotours
scraped_itos.description: Gambia birding tours are seen as great introduction to African birding and will surely leave you yearning for more from this amazing birding and wildlife
scraped_itos.content: Gambia Birding Tours Go to: Senegal birding tours | Birding tours to Africa and its islands | All our Birding Tours Gambia birding tours are seen as a great introduction to African birding and will surely leave you yearning for more from this amazing birding and wildlife continent. The Republic of The Gambia (â€œThe Gambiaâ€ hereafter) is the smallest country of mainland Africa. The entire country is surrounded by Senegal, except for the west coast which sits on the Atlantic Ocean. The Gambia really is a tiny country at just 4,127 square miles (10,689 square kilometers) which would make it the third smallest mainland US state, just behind Connecticut. The Gambiaâ€™s population is around 2.2 million people, about the same as New Mexico, with around 413,000 people living within the urban area of the capital, Banjul. Banjul is a relatively modern city, only being founded in 1816, and was the center when The Gambia was a colony of the British Empire. The first records of The Gambia are from the 9th and 10th centuries when the area was visited by Arab traders from North Africa. Later The Gambia became part of the Mali Empire, before the Portuguese Empire arrived and sold the trade rights of The Gambia to the British Empire, ruled by Queen Elizabeth I. During the 17th century the British Empire and French Empire fought for control of the region before Britain finally invaded and occupied the country in 1758. While France retained some control, what remained was ceded to Britain in 1856. The modern boundaries of The Gambia were formed in 1889 and The Gambia finally gained independence from Britain in 1963. Read More About Gambia During the three centuries of the transatlantic slave trade, it is thought that as many as three million people were transported from The Gambia and the surrounding region to colonies across the world. In 1807 the British Empire abolished the slave trade but failed in doing this in The Gambia until 1906. The geography of the Gambia is dominated by The Gambia River which flows down the spine of the country. The surrounding land is flat and a mixture of savanna, forest-savanna, and mangroves. The Gambia is only 31 miles (50 kilometers) wide at its widest point and as such the climate is consistent across the country. The tropical climate brings rain between June and November along with high temperatures. From November until May the climate is dry, and temperatures are lower. The Gambiaâ€™s bird list is currently 620 species (following International Ornithological Congress (IOC) taxonomy v11.1 in May 2021), an incredible total for such a small country. There are obviously far too many species to list here but some of the many highlight species from our The Gambia: Gateway to Africa tour include Egyptian Plover (a most-wanted bird for many world birders and a monotypic family), African Paradise Flycatcher, African Pygmy Goose, Hamerkop (another monotypic family), Guinea Turaco, Violet Turaco, Northern Carmine Bee-eater, Swallow-tailed Bee-eater, Oriole Warbler, White-spotted Flufftail, African Finfoot, Abyssinian Ground Hornbill, Martial Eagle, African Fish Eagle, Bateleur, Red-necked Falcon, Marabou Stork, Pygmy Sunbird, Exclamatory Paradise Whydah, Black Crowned Crane, Long-tailed Nightjar, Blue Malkoha, Green-headed Sunbird, White-crested Helmetshrike, Splendid Starling, White-breasted Cuckooshrike, Grey-headed Kingfisher, Pelâ€™s Fishing Owl, African Wood Owl, Greyish Eagle-Owl, Verreauxâ€™s Eagle-Owl, White-backed Night Heron, Spotted Honeyguide, Bronze-winged Courser, Red-throated Bee-eater, Four-banded Sandgrouse, Stone Partridge, and much more. We will also come across a wide range of Western Palearctic migrants during our Gambia birding tour including many passerines, shorebirds (waders), herons, bitterns, egrets, birds of prey, and swifts. It promises to be a wonderful birding experience. This Gambia birding tour is designed to be the perfect introduction to African birding. We will be staying in the famous Senegambia Beach Hotel during our time on the coast which offers all the facilities of the best hotels in Europe. With the bonus of around 230 species of birds recorded in the hotel grounds and immediate area, it also allows for excellent photo opportunities. When we travel upriver, we will stay in comfortable and safe eco-lodges with the birds again on our doorstep, and while on our journey we make use of safe and comfortable vehicles. Gambia: Winter Escape Birdwatching Holiday January 2026/2027 View More Download Gambia ItinerariesGambia: Winter Escape Birdwatching Holiday January 2026/2027Gambia Gallery View Larger Egyptian Plover View Larger Abyssinian Ground Hornbill View Larger Black-faced FirefinchMattias Hofstede View Larger African Finfoot View Larger Goliath Heron View Larger Bateleur View Larger Hamerkop View Larger Northern Carmine Bee-eater View Larger Pel's Fishing Owl View Larger Palm-nut Vulture View Larger Saddle-billed Stork View Larger White-crowned Lapwing View Larger Swallow-tailed Bee-eater View Larger African Fish Eagle View Larger Black HeronMattias Hofstede View Larger Spotted HoneyguideMattias Hofstede View Larger White-crested Helmetshrike View Larger Martial Eagle View Larger Yellow-crowned Gonolek View Larger Senegal Parrot Testimonials from our Gambia birding tours Senegal and The Gambia is a delightful destination and is full of birds. For those that have not experienced Africa before, it is an excellent introduction to African birding. The river trips are wonderful and it is difficult to know where to look first with bee-eaters, kingfishers of multi colors assaulting the mind. Dylan is a very able leader whom we enjoy travelling with as his African birding knowledge is first class as well as having a delightful personality well able to overcome problems that inevitably arise in African countries. The climate of sun and heat is a welcome relief of grey, cold miserable weather experienced in the northern hemisphere in winter. Accommodation is basic but adequate and local eateries are interesting but would not win any medals for hygiene. Sue - On Senegal/The Gambia and Dylan - December 2022

Gambia staat beter bekend als â€˜the Smiling Coast of Africaâ€™. En dat is niet zonder reden! Ontdek zelf de tropische stranden, oprechte gastvrijheid en de culturele pracht van Afrika en boek nu je vakantie Gambia bij Corendon! Goedkope vakantie Gambia Hoewel Gambia het kleinste land van Afrika is, heeft het een grootse natuurlijke schoonheid. De 70 kilometer lange kustlijn met hagelwitte zandstranden is alleen al een goede reden om voor een vakantie Gambia te kiezen. Heerlijk zonnen op het strand, relaxen met een cocktail in je handâ€¦ Maar Gambia biedt veel meer dan zon, zee en strand. Trek ook het binnenland in en bewonder de uitgestrekte mangrovebossen waar onder andere meer dan 450 verschillende soorten vogels leven. Gambia vakantie informatie Weer Gambia Gambia is een tropisch vakantieparadijs met warm zeewater, wuivende palmbomen en ruim 7 tot 8 uur zon per dag. Van november tot en met mei kun je tijdens een vakantie Gambia genieten van een gemiddelde temperatuur van 21 tot 27 graden. En de zon, die schijnt het hele jaar door! Het is dan ook niet zo vreemd dat Gambia een geliefde winterzonbestemming is. Bekijk onze uitgebreide informatie over het klimaat van gambia. Gambia bezienswaardigheden Varen over â€˜The Gambiaâ€™ De belangrijkste toeristische attractie van Gambia is de gelijknamige rivier â€˜The Gambiaâ€™. Deze rivier is de levensader van Gambia en stroomt over de volledige lengte van het land. Het is een absolute must om een boottocht te maken tijdens je vakantie Gambia. Het water wordt omzoomd door de groene jungle, waar je vogels en misschien zelfs ook nijlpaarden of krokodillen kunt spotten. Afdingen op de markt in Banjul Wil je het echte Gambiaanse leven proeven? Doe dan je boodschappen op de markt! Struin door smalle straatjes met zelfgemaakte kraampjes en tik bijzondere souvenirs op de kop. Je kunt het zo gek niet bedenken of het is te koop: etenswaren, kleding, witgoedâ€¦ Aanraders om te bezoeken tijdens je vakantie Gambia zijn de Albert Market in Banjul of de Serrekunda Market in Serrekunda. Corendon heeft alle accommodaties met grote zorg geselecteerd om je vakantie Gambia zo aangenaam mogelijk te maken. Je kunt het zo gek niet bedenken of het is te koop: etenswaren, kleding, witgoedâ€¦ Aanraders om te bezoeken tijdens je vakantie Gambia zijn de Albert Market in Banjul of de Serrekunda Market in Serrekunda. Hotels en Appartementen in Gambia Corendon heeft een gevarieerd aanbod aan appartementen en hotels in Gambia. Corendon heeft alle accommodaties met grote zorg geselecteerd om je vakantie Gambia zo aangenaam mogelijk te maken. Bij de selectie van de accommodaties wordt onder andere gelet op de ligging t.o.v. stranden, eetgelegenheden en eventuele stadscentra. Gerelateerd Meer vakanties in Gambia Alle vakanties Gambia Luxe vakantie Gambia All Inclusive Gambia Last minute Gambia Hotels Gambia Gambia met kinderen Algemene informatie Hoofdstad: Banjul Aantal inwoners: 1.883.051 (2013) Oppervlakte: 11.295 km2 Taal: Engels Religie: 90% Islamitisch, 9% Christelijk Tijdsverschil: 2 uur vroeger in de zomer, 1 uur vroeger in winter Munteenheid: Dalasi Regeringsvorm: Republiek Elektriciteit: 220V, 50 hertz wisselstroom BNP per hoofd: $2.000 (2011) Landnummer: +220 Lokale noodnummers: Ambulance 116, politie 117, brandweer 118 Eten en drinken In de vakantiegebieden zijn de meeste restaurants helemaal op de toeristen ingesteld. Je hebt er keuze uit allerlei restaurants, van Chinees tot Mexicaans. In de steden kun je heel goedkoop Afrikaans eten, maar wees voorzichtig en let goed op de hygiÃ«ne! Men gebruikt in Gambia veel rijst, kip en vis, bereiding geschiedt meestal op een vuur. Het water dat in Gambia uit de kraan komt is in veel hotels van redelijk goede kwaliteit, maar het drinken ervan wordt afgeraden. Daarom is ons advies om flessen mineraalwater te kopen. Een van de weinige fabrieken in Gambia is de Banyul Brewery, hier wordt het goed drinkbare Gambiaanse bier Julbrew (groene flesjes) gebrouwen. Taal Engels is de officiÃ«le taal in Gambia, met name bij de overheid, in het onderwijs, in de rechtspraak en natuurlijk in de toeristencentra. Ruim de helft van de Gambianen spreekt naast Engels een eigen stamtaal.Natuur Gambia is een paradijs voor vogelliefhebbers. Er werden tot nu toe ongeveer 450 verschillende soorten geteld, en nog steeds worden nieuwe soorten ontdekt. Helaas zijn alle grote zoogdieren vrijwel allemaal uitgestorven door de jacht die in de 19 de eeuw op ze gemaakt werd. De welbekende 'African Big Five' zal je in Gambia niet vinden want olifanten, neushoorns, giraffen, leeuwen, buffels, grote antilopen, hebben hun heil ergens anders gezocht. Diep landinwaarts komen nog wel nijlpaarden en krokodillen in de Gambia rivier voor. Verschillende kleine apensoorten zoals de fluweelaap en de huzaaraap komen overal voor. Chimpansees leven alleen nog in het Baboon Island National park. Verder zijn er nog kleine antilopensoorten, aardvarkens en wrattenzwijnen. Gambia heeft een aantal nationale parken en reservaten waar deze dieren te bewonderen zijn.Feestdagen 1 januari: Nieuwjaar 14 februari: Onafhankelijkheidsdag 27 februari: Hemelvaart Mohammed (Isra en Mi'raj) 28 februari â€“ 30 maart: Ramadan 8 maart: Internationale Vrouwendag 30 maart: Suikerfeest (Eid al-Fitr) 6 juni: Offerfeest (Eid al-Adha) 5 september: Geboortedag Mohammed (Milad un-Nabi) 25 & 26 december: Kerstmis 31 december: OudjaarAchtergrond / Geschiedenis De vroegste schriftelijke verwijzing naar Gambia is vastgelegd in het verslag van Hanno de Carthaag. De Carthagen leefden ongeveer 470 voor Christus in het oude Europa / Middellandse Zeegebied en maakten vele intercontinentale reizen en stonden zo in contact met verre beschavingen. Het eerste Portugese contact met Gambia werd gelegd in 1456 toen een Portugese verkenningsvloot op het huidige James Island landde. Zij vestigden handelsposten waar zij zout, ijzer, buskruit en geweren verhandelden in ruil voor ivoor, goud, ebbenhout en slaven. Begin 17e eeuw kampten de Portugese kolonies in BraziliÃ« met een arbeiderstekort, wat er toe leidde dat dit tekort aangevuld werd vanuit West Afrika door middel van slaven. Hierna volgden de Nederlanders en de Fransen het voorbeeld waardoor Portugal zijn monopolistische positie verloor. De slaven werden tewerkgesteld in onder andere Amerika, Jamaica , Suriname en de Antillen. In 1661 namen de Britten definitief bezit van James Island en dit was het begin van de Britse heerschappij over Gambia. De Fransen namen bezit van wat tegenwoordig Senegal is. Pas in 1807 werd onder Britse heerschappij de slavernij afgeschaft, maar de Britten bleven Gambia wel bezetten. Na de Tweede Wereld Oorlog kwamen er steeds meer stemmen voor zelfbeschikking, maar pas op 18 februari 1965 kreeg Gambia politieke onafhankelijkheid van Groot-BrittanniÃ«. Op 24 april 1970 werd Gambia een zelfstandige republiek. Duurzamer op vakantie Ã‰cht duurzame vliegvakanties bestaan helaas nog niet. Maar als je je voetafdruk een (klein) beetje wilt verkleinen, kun je bij het boeken van je vliegvakantie Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) kopen. Wat dat precies is lees je hier. Met het kopen van SAF draag je bij aan een lagere CO2-uitstoot van je vliegreis. Je kunt daarnaast kiezen voor een gecertificeerde accommodatie. Deze hotels voldoen aan de hoogste duurzaamheidsstandaarden en zijn daarom een betere keuze voor je vakantie. Maak je gebruik van een transfer naar je hotel? Gemiddeld genomen vervoert een bus meer mensen dan een taxi, waardoor de CO2-uitstoot per passagier lager wordt. Een bustransfer is daarom vaak een duurzamere keuze dan een privÃ©transfer. Op de bestemming Gambia ligt aan de westkust van Afrika en is volledig ingesloten door Senegal. De natuurlijke omgeving van Gambia wordt gekenmerkt door de Gambia-rivier die dwars door het land stroomt. Langs de rivier en de zee vind je mangroves en een overvloed aan vogel- en vissoorten. De mangroves zijn belangrijk, want ze vormen natuurlijke barriÃ¨res tegen bodemerosie. Het is belangrijk om je te realiseren dat Gambia een land is dat voor grote uitdagingen staat als het gaat om natuurbescherming, armoede en gelijke rechten. Als je Gambia bezoekt, zal je zien dat er veel afval langs de weg ligt en dat mensen in armoedige huizen of op straat leven. Het kan daarom even schakelen zijn als je uit het vliegtuig stapt. Maar de meeste Gambianen zullen je met open armen ontvangen. In Gambia zijn de meeste mensen moslim. De vrouwen zijn vaak gesluierd. Het is respectvol om zelf ook bedekkende kleding te dragen, vooral als je de toeristische gebieden uit gaat. Muziek en dans spelen een centrale rol in het Gambiaanse leven en lokale festivals en vieringen zijn vaak gevuld met traditionele muziek en kleurrijke dansuitvoeringen. Schroom niet om zelf mee te dansen, de Gambianen zijn vriendelijk en verwelkomen je graag. Bewust op excursie Hoewel je op onze bestemmingen tal van avontuurlijke excursies en activiteiten kunt ondernemen, is het belangrijk om je bewust te zijn van de mogelijke impact ervan op de natuur en cultuur. Over het algemeen geldt: zo lang je mensen, dieren en natuur respectvol behandelt, kun je met een gerust hart van je vakantie genieten. Klik hier voor een overzicht van handige do's en don'ts tijdens excursies. De Gambiaanse mangroves kun je het beste bewonderen vanuit een kayak. Er zijn verschillende nature reserves die je in Gambia of het naastgelegen Senegal kunt bezoeken. Ook een batikworkshop is een aanrader: hier leer je hoe typisch Afrikaanse stoffen worden bedrukt. Als je meer wilt leren over de geschiedenis van het land kun je James Island en het Fort James bezoeken. Het binnenland van Gambia geeft een andere kijk op het land. Spreek een lokale taxichauffeur aan om je erheen te brengen en je de mooiste plekjes te laten zien. Maatschappelijke impact Er zijn verschillende manieren om de lokale bevolking of de natuur op je vakantiebestemming te helpen of te ondersteunen. Vraag je lokale reisleiding naar zijn of haar tips voor goede doelen of sociale initiatieven. Iedere bestemming heeft namelijk eigen uitdagingen op het gebied van klimaat of maatschappelijke kwesties. Corendon steunt in Gambia de Bakau Basketball Academy (BBA): een plek waar jongeren iedere dag van de week samen kunnen sporten onder begeleiding van twee oud-profbasketballers. Veel kinderen in de achterstandswijken van Banjul missen rolmodellen in hun directe omgeving. Dankzij de BBA hebben ze de nodige afleiding en krijgen ze perspectief. De Nederlandse Ed Spier reisde al vier keer op onze kosten naar Gambia om de BBA te helpen groeien. Vluchtduur De vluchtduur naar de luchthaven van Banjul bedraagt ca. 6.15 uur. Bekijk de vliegtijd naar Gambia. Je dient er rekening mee te houden dat de hierboven genoemde vluchttijd slechts ter indicatie is en er altijd tijdspelingen mogelijk kunnen zijn.Transfer De transfer naar je accommodatie is niet inbegrepen, maar optioneel bij te boeken. Klik hier voor meer informatie en de kosten. Transfertijd Vanaf Banjul luchthaven naar: Bijilo: ca. 20 minuten Kololi: ca. 25 minuten Kotu: ca. 30 minuten Cape Point: ca. 40 minuten Banjul: ca. 40 minuten Je dient er rekening mee te houden dat de hierboven genoemde tijden slechts ter indicatie zijn en er altijd tijdspelingen mogelijk kunnen zijn. Legitimatie Klik hier voor alle informatie over legitimatie, een eventueel visum en formaliteiten op het gebied van gezondheid. Verkeer Het autoverkeer in Gambia is onveilig door onder andere de slechte staat van de wegen en voertuigen. Bij een ongeluk krijgt de chauffeur meestal de schuld. Houd er bovendien rekening mee dat er nergens verkeersborden staan.Openbaar vervoer Reizen met het openbaar vervoer in Gambia is alleen aan te bevelen aan de ervaren reiziger. Er is een busnetwerk en er varen verschillende veerboten waarmee je de Gambia Rivier kunt oversteken.Taxi Men kan drie soorten taxi's vinden in Gambia: De bushtaxi: een busje welke dient als een soort openbaar vervoer en zeer goedkoop is. De groene taxi: deze is bedoeld voor toeristen en mogen je ook in het toeristengebied ophalen. Het is verstandig van tevoren de ritprijs af te spreken. De gele taxi's: bestemd voor privÃ© vervoer voor Gambianen, deze mogen niet in het toeristengebied komenAutohuur Autohuur in Gambia is mogelijk maar wordt afgeraden gezien het chaotische verkeer. Tijdsverschil Het is in Gambia tijdens onze wintermaanden 1 uur vroeger en tijdens onze zomermaanden 2 uur vroeger.Geldzaken De Gambiaanse munt is de Dalasi (D), onderverdeeld in 100 Bututs. Er zijn (beperkt) munten van 1, 5, 10, 25 en 50 Bututs en er is een munt van 1 Dalasi. Bankbiljetten zijn er van 5, 10, 20, 25, 50, 100 en 200 Dalasi. In Gambia vind je op een beperkt aantal plaatsen pinautomaten, die creditcards (alleen Visa en Mastercard) en Maestro-bankpassen (moeten â€˜aanâ€™ staan voor buiten Europa) accepteren. Houd er rekening mee dat het aantal automaten beperkt is en buiten bedrijf kunnen zijn, door bijvoorbeeld storingen. Met een bankpas kan alleen geld uit een automaat gepint worden, met een creditcard kan naast het geld pinnen uit een automaat ook betaald worden bij hotels, sommige restaurants en excursies. Het blijft verstandig ook contanten bij je te hebben. Je kunt je euro's ter plaatse omwisselen in de hotels of bij speciaal daarvoor bestemde wisselkantoren die veelvuldig te vinden zijn in het toeristengebied. Let daarbij op de koers. Deze kan per locatie variÃ«ren. Je kunt ook je excursies betalen met een creditcard of bankpas. Houd er dan wel rekening mee dat de kosten in de meeste gevallen hoger uitkomen. Ook de bank in Nederland kan nog een vergoeding voor een betaling buiten de eurozone vragen. Je kunt dit voorkomen door contante euroâ€™s mee te nemen. In dit geval dien je wel te bedenken dat het meenemen van grote hoeveelheden contant geld risicoâ€™s met zich meebrengt en dat het geld bij verlies of diefstal niet verzekerd is. Zet je pinpas â€˜aanâ€™ Voor je veiligheid hebben de meeste banken betaalpassen standaard geblokkeerd voor gebruik buiten Europa. Als je op vakantie gaat buiten Europa kunt je je pinpas kosteloos â€˜aanâ€™zetten bij je bank. De bank kan je meer informatie geven. Accommodaties en borg Let op! Het is gebruikelijk in Gambia dat bij aankomst in de accommodatie een borg wordt gevraagd, deze kun je doorgaans met cash of creditcard voldoen. Tijdens je verblijf kun je met deze borg consumpties â€˜op rekeningâ€™ bestellen. Wel zo handig! Elektriciteit Het voltage in Gambia is 220 Volt, adapters kun je het beste vanuit Nederland meenemen. Het zijn Engelse stekkerdozen dus reisstekkers zijn gewenst.

scraped_itos.content: Search HolidaysRecommended HotelsExperiencesAll DestinationsFind Out MorePopular Holidays Holidays to The Gambia have exotic wildlife, palm-packed beaches and haggle-friendly markets in the bag. Bite-sized AfricaSqueezed onto Africaâ€™s west coast, The Gambiaâ€™s basically taken a chunk out of Senegalâ€™s shoreline. Savannahs and sandy beaches, baboons and buffalos, markets and mangroves â€“ it packs a culture-blazing itinerary. Plus, its small size is actually a perk â€“ it means you can cram more sights into one break. Not only that, but itâ€™s only six hours away and in the same time zone as the UK, and the official language is English, so you get winter sun without the stress. Chimps and crocsThe Gambia goes wild with wallowing hippos, chimps swinging along the Gambia River and Nile crocodiles at the Kiang West National Park. Africa's known for its safaris, and this spot doesnâ€™t disappoint, either. Tonnes of nature reserves and national parks let you inside these animalsâ€™ natural habitats, at a respectful distance, of course. Look up, too. The Abuko Nature Reserve alone is home to more than 300 species of exotic bird to suit you twitchers. Beach lifeWhen youâ€™re not wildlife-watching, you can be sunbathing on strips of sand. Kotu and Kololi are both top resorts â€“ Kololi is backed by a big strip of bars and foodie places, as well. But the wildlife is never far away. In Bakau, Cape Point beach rolls down to the bird-squawking wetlands of Cape Creek. And on the other side of the river, Jinack Islandâ€™s 11-kilometre stretch of au naturel shoreline will have you dreaming up your desert island discs selection. Post-sunset shenanigansDaytimes in The Gambia are at the chilled end of the scale â€“ wildlife-watching and sunbathing will probably take up a big chunk of space on your itinerary. Come nighttime, though, thereâ€™s no shortage of bars, clubs and restaurants to get your teeth into. Kololiâ€™s the countryâ€™s nightlife hub. Here, the famous Senegambia Strip buzzes with energy after dark â€“ once a row of roadside shacks, itâ€™s now the go-to spot for eating out, mingling with the locals and late-night clubbing. Off-beat adventuresLike a lot of developing countries, The Gambia comes with a few unique charms â€“ but theyâ€™re all part of the authentic experience. The roads are on the bumpy side, Wi-Fi isnâ€™t always as reliable as what youâ€™re used to at home, and not all hotel lobbies and restaurants have air con. Youâ€™ll probably notice the odd power cut during your stay, too. However, all of this makes for an adventure to remember â€“ and the smiling locals, tropical shores and off-the-beaten-track experiences youâ€™ll get here will more than make up for the lack of mod-cons. scraped_itos.title: Gambia Senegal Wildlife Tour | Fleewinter Destination
scraped_itos.description: Explore Gambia and Senegal's diverse wildlife on this immersive tour, encountering vibrant birdlife, primates, and unique ecosystems.
scraped_itos.content: Gambia Senegal Wildlife Tour | Fleewinter Destination Request a quote Notice: JavaScript is required for this content. Ã— Search Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour 8 days from Â£2,320 per person The Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour makes a fabulous introduction to the wildlife of Africa and, for bird lovers, itâ€™s an absolute must. See monkeys, giraffes, zebra and more, not to mention some of the 540-plus species of birds found here. This exciting itinerary combines three unique places to stay, a floating river lodge deep in the heart of Makasutu Forest, a small boutique hotel by the beach and glamping in a Senegalese wildlife reserve. We recommend a minimum of 8 days, but longer itineraries are also available. Suitable for couples and families with children 16 years and older. Itineraries for families with younger children are also available. Your Itinerary Day 1 - Arrive in The Gambia Arrive in the afternoon at the Banjul Airport where your driver will meet you for your transfer (45 minutes) to the stunning Mandina Lodges in the heart of Makasutu Forest. Here youâ€™ll find your floating lodge on a tributary of the River Gambia. That evening, dine alfresco under a thatched cabana beneath a star-studded African sky. Accommodation Day 2 - Explore Makasutu forest and waterways Having enjoyed a coffee or tea on your verandah watching the forest awake, head out for a walk with your guide and learn more about the flora and fauna of the area including the large troop of baboons that live here. Once back at the lodges, take a leisurely late breakfast and spend the rest of the day relaxing by the river or the pool, watching the birds that regularly visit. In the late afternoon, your guide will take you out in a canoe to explore the mangroves and waterways. As well as the varied birdlife, youâ€™ll see local fishermen and, at low tide, women collecting oysters from the exposed mangrove roots. Accommodation Day 3 - Sunset cruise On your second morning, head out with your guide along the river by canoe or on another forest walk, perhaps visiting the Gambia Horse and Donkey Trust. Chat to one of their volunteers for a fascinating insight into the work of this charity. In the late afternoon, join other guests at Mandina for a cruise along the river in a motorboat to see flocks of birds coming home to roost as the sun sets behind the mangroves while enjoying a bottle of South African house wine (one bottle per couple). Accommodation Day 4 - Go wild in Senegal Start the day early with a private transfer to Banjulâ€™s ferry port from where youâ€™ll cross the River Gambia. This is an adventure in itself with a colourful collection of vehicles, people, and often animals streaming onto the ferry. Your guide will look after you all the way. From here itâ€™s just a short drive across the border to Senegal and Fathala Wildlife Reserve. Staying in luxury safari tents, with air-conditioning and an ensuite bathroom, youâ€™ll soon settle in. That afternoon set off on a sunset game drive through the African bush for the chance to see the rare West African giant derby eland as well as zebra, giraffes, rhino, buffalo, warthogs, several species of monkeys and numerous bird species. Accommodation Day 5 - Discover Senegal Visit a traditional Senegalese market and bakery and learn about local life. Meet local artisans, see traditional crafts and fabrics, taste baobab juice and be back at Fathala in time for lunch. In the late afternoon, join a guided walk through the Africa bush to learn about the plants and smaller animals that live on the reserve. This is an excellent opportunity for bird photography. Thereâ€™s no guarantee what you may see, but frequently sighted bird species include the Abyssinian roller, the rose-ringed parakeet, the western red-billed hornbill, the long-tailed glossy starling and many more. Accommodation Day 6 - Back to The Gambia Itâ€™s time to return to The Gambia and transfer to Leoâ€™s Beach Resort set in an elevated position overlooking a quiet sandy beach. The rest of your day is free to spend relaxing by the pool or the beach. Alternatively, the nearby village of Tanji is a short taxi ride away. Here you can see the local fishing boats known as pirogues being unloaded and watch the hustle and bustle of the fish market. Itâ€™s a mesmerising, colourful sight set against a cacophony as gulls squawk overhead, and people haggle over the price of fish. Accommodation Day 7 - Birdwatching Rise early to make the most of your time with your birding expert. If thereâ€™s a particular habitat or species youâ€™re interested in, let us know; otherwise, leave it to your guide to take you to the best birdwatching location on any specific day. Likely sites include Abuko Nature Reserve, home to approximately 250 species of birds, including giant kingfishers and turaco; Brufut Forest for its array of woodland birds, or nearby Tanji Bird Reserve, not far from your hotel. Accommodation Day 8 - Bid farewell to the Smiling Coast of West Africa After a leisurely breakfast, with plenty of time for a walk along the beach or a last swim in the pool, leave Leoâ€™s Beach Resort around mid-morning to check-in for your flight home. Details - This Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour itinerary costs from Â£2,320 per person based on 2 sharing. What's included? Includes: Prices start from Â£2,320 per person Fullboard at Mandina Lodge and Leoâ€™s Beach Hotel; and B&B at Fathala Wildlife Reserve Transfers (including ferry crossing) An English-speaking guide available throughout your stay Fathala Wildlife Reserve game drive, village visit and bushwalk All trips are ATOL protected or ABTA bonded to ensure you are fully covered Make a booking Ngala Lodge A unique, cliff-top boutique hotel with stunning ocean views and one of the finest restaurants in The Gambia. More Coco Ocean Resort & Spa The elegant Moroccan inspired Coco Ocean, by a tranquil neverending beach, is one of the most luxurious hotels in The Gambia. More Leo's Beach Hotel This intimate, contemporary eco-friendly hotel boasts excellent sea views from itâ€™s elevated position by a quiet golden sand beach. More White Horse Residence An eco-friendly, tranquil retreat with seven thatched lodges in a lush green tropical garden overlooking the ocean and a beautiful sandy beach. More Ocean Bay Hotel A well-established, family-friendly hotel by one of the best beaches in The Gambia. More Mandina Lodge A unique, tranquil hideaway, these stunning eco-lodges on a tributary of the River Gambia, lie deep in the heart of Makasutu Forest. More Fathala Wildlife Reserve See zebra, giraffes, monkeys, rhino and more while glamping at this wildlife reserve in Senegal, just across the border from The Gambia. scraped_itos.content: Gambia Gambia Holidays Gambiaâ€¦The Smiling Coast of Africa! Holidays in The Gambia Gambia is a small West African country bordered by Senegal on three sides with a narrow Atlantic coastline and is known as â€˜The Smiling Coast of Africaâ€™ thanks to the warm and friendly welcome youâ€™ll receive from the locals. Gambia is perfect for laid-back beach holidays on endless, uncrowded swathes of golden sands alongside the 50-mile-long shoreline. Youâ€™ll also get to experience the countryâ€™s rich and diverse history, amazing natural beauty, thrilling activities, eclectic wildlife, and authentic cuisine. And, whatâ€™s more, Gambia is only just over six hours flying time from the UK and is on the same time-zone, so no jet-lag! When is the best time to visit Gambia? Gambia offers a sub-tropical climate with between six to 12 hours of daily sunshine throughout the year and average monthly temperatures between 24oC and 27oC. The country also has two distinct seasons â€“ the dry season from November to May and the wet season from June to October. Where is the best place to stay in Gambia? Discover an array of places to stay in Gambia to suit every budget. Beach-lovers flock to the main resorts of the long-established Kololi and the vibrant and newly developed Kotu, while nature lovers can check into floating lodges on the River Gambia. Whether youâ€™re seeking bed and breakfast, self-catering, half-board, or all-inclusive; Hays Travel will find you the best accommodation for your Gambia holiday. Travel guide The Gambia is popular with all ages and tastes including families, couples, friends, and single travellers. From sun-worshippers and activity fans to avid explorers and culture enthusiasts, holidays to Gambia have something for everyone. Best time to visit: November-May Average flight time: 6 Hours 20 Minutes Most suited for: Couples Currency: Gambian Dalasi Time Difference: -1 Hour BEACH LIFE AND CITIES Spend a relaxing morning or afternoon enjoying the African sunshine and swimming in the azure ocean that laps the golden stretches of sands in the vibrant resorts of Kololi and Katu. If youâ€™re seeking splendid isolation, escape to the less-crowded and secluded beaches at Cape Point and Brufut. City-wise you can head to the capital Banjul on St Maryâ€™s Island, where Gambia meets the Atlantic Ocean â€“ here you can admire the colonial buildings like the Gambia National Museum, shop for local handicrafts at lively Albert Market, and admire the architectural marvel of Arch 22, the gateway to the city. THINGS TO SEE AND DO! Tee off in the sunshine on the fairways of Koloki Golf Course and Fajara Golf Club. With over 600 species of birds indigenous to Gambia, itâ€™s a birdwatcherâ€™s delight, so donâ€™t forget your binoculars. Follow the walking trails through Abuko Nature Reserve to spot Vervet, Western Red Colobus, and Patas Monkeys. Get up close to the 100 crocodiles who live in Katchikally Crocodile Pool and take a relaxing cruise past birds, wildlife, and mangroves on the Gambia River. Head to Bakau to pick up woodcarvings at the craft market or see how fabrics are made on a visit to Serekunda Batik Factory. Delve into the nationâ€™s rich and vivid history at the iconic Kunta Kinteh Island, Wassu Stone Circles, and Fort Bullen. Food & Drink Prepare to embark on a culinary journey that celebrates the rich cultural heritage of The Gambia. From traditional Gambian dishes to international cuisines like Italian, Chinese, Indian, and Lebanese; the dining scene is a fusion of flavours that will delight your palate. Typical dishes youâ€™ll see on local menus include Akara (black-eyed pea fritters), Benachin (one pot stew with fish or chicken), Domoada (peanut-based dish), freshly-baked Talapa bread, and Yassa (chillies, limes, onions, mustard, and stock) with beef, fish, prawns, or vegetables. Non-alcoholic drinks to sample include Baobab Juice and Wonjo Juice and also the mildly-alcoholic Palm Wine. scraped_itos.content: Gambia Holidays 2025/2026Weâ€™ll say it up front â€“ Gambia isnâ€™t your average holiday destination. With gold sand beaches, an incredible wealth of wildlife, energetic craft markets and some of the friendliest locals youâ€™re bound to meet on your travels, this little African country is in a holiday genre of its own. TRAVEL AWARE â€“ STAYING SAFE AND HEALTHY ABROAD (foreign office travel advice)Gambia Holiday Deals 2025/2026 View more dealsThe smiling coast of AfricaGambia is a slim country along the western coast of mainland Africa, hugged almost completely by Senegal, minus its narrow coastline. Itâ€™s the smallest country in all of Africa, named after the river snaking through the land. Gambia first entered the sights of tourists after a group of Scandinavian holidaymakers catapulted it onto the scene in the sixties, but the country itself did the rest. Holidays to Gambia combine swathes of beaches with exotic wildlife, and locals so welcoming that the country has earned itself the nickname â€˜the smiling coast of Africaâ€™. Key Facts for Gambia: Currency: Gambian Dalasi (GMD) Language: English Timezone: GMT +0 Avg. Flight Time: 5 hours 30 minutes (from London) Visas: You do not need a visa if youâ€™re travelling to Gambia for up to 28 days. RegionsBijiloCape PointKololiKotu BeachFurther ReadingArticlesBest HotelsFood And Drink Location Where is Gambia? Where's best to stay in Gambia?From lively beach resorts to peaceful coastal escapes, Gambiaâ€™s top regions each offer something unique, whether youâ€™re after wildlife, nightlife or sun-soaked relaxation. Beaches in GambiaGambiaâ€™s coastline offers sun-soaked escapes with a mix of lively beaches and tranquil stretches. Bijilo Beach is a peaceful spot with soft sands and gentle waves, perfect for families or couples. Nearby cafes and small restaurants serve traditional local dishes, and you might even spot monkeys from Bijilo Forest Park nearby. Cape Point features golden sands and calm Atlantic waters, ideal for swimming, splashing around with the kids or a quiet stroll. Its rocky backdrop and scenic views make it a photographerâ€™s dream. Kololi Beach is a lively and bustling option, lined with sunbeds and a promenade full of bars, restaurants and shops. Itâ€™s the heart of Gambiaâ€™s beach life, perfect for those seeking a social vibe with plenty of amenities on hand. Kotu Beach stretches for miles, offering a quieter, natural escape. You can explore tidal pools, spot birdlife in the mangroves, or simply relax on the soft sand with the gentle surf. Itâ€™s perfect for nature lovers or those looking for their own tranquil spot. Wildlife in GambiaGambia has some of the best wildlife reserves and forests in West Africa, making it a fantastic destination for nature lovers and animal enthusiasts alike. Just south of Cape Point in the town of Bakau is the Kachikally Crocodile Pool, a sacred site where crocodiles glide through the water. Traditionally used for fertility rituals, itâ€™s also a fascinating place to see these ancient reptiles up close. The Bijilo Forest Park, also called Monkey Park, is a protected area home to playful monkeys, diverse birdlife, and shaded walking trails â€“ perfect for a peaceful nature stroll. A short drive south of Banjul takes you to the Abuko Nature Reserve, Gambiaâ€™s first official wildlife reserve. Here youâ€™ll encounter monkeys, reptiles like crocodiles and cobras, and more than 200 bird species, making it a birdwatcherâ€™s paradise. For those seeking a true African adventure, head on a safari excursion from Kololi or Banjul, along the Gambia River or into the bush. Spot hippos, giraffes, lions, and other iconic wildlife in their natural habitat, making for an unforgettable experience. Craft markets in GmbiaLocal craft markets are the heart of any Gambian city. Here, locals display their wares, fresh fruits and vegetables pile high, and youâ€™ll see the iconic visual of women balancing wicker baskets atop their heads. Cape Point Markets are small but charming. At the Bakau Craft Market, youâ€™ll find stalls selling handmade jewelry, textiles, and souvenirs, perfect for picking up unique keepsakes while experiencing local life. The markets in Kotu Beach offer a mix of beachfront shopping and local culture. The Kotu Craft Village is a standout, with colorful fabrics, handmade crafts, and tropical fruits, giving visitors a taste of authentic Gambian crafts. Senegambia Craft Market in Kololi has a lively community vibe. Stalls are packed with traditional carvings, paintings, and woven goods, while street performers and local musicians add to the energetic atmosphere, giving a true taste of Gambian culture. Albert Market in Banjul is the countryâ€™s largest and most famous market. Itâ€™s a bustling hub of activity, where you can haggle for leather goods, wooden carvings, spices, and local delicacies. Places to go in GambiaGambia may be small, but itâ€™s packed with attractions that will give you a taste of the local culture, nature and beach charm. In Kololi, Bijilo Forest Park is a huge (51 hectare!) coastal reserve renowned for its rich biodiversity. Stroll through the trails that wind through the dense forest and catch glimpses of vervet monkeys, red colobus monkeys, and over 130 bird species. Itâ€™s a tranquil escape for nature enthusiasts and families seeking a blend of wildlife and coastal beauty. The Senegambia Strip is the heart of Kololiâ€™s vibrant tourist scene. This bustling area is lined with a variety of shops, restaurants, bars, and nightclubs, offering a lively atmosphere, whether youâ€™re after an evening stroll, some local cuisine, or the energetic nightlife. If you love natural charm and local culture, head to Kotu Beach for leisurely walks and birdwatching. Browse the markets, sunbathe on the soft sand or try your hand at beach volleyball and soak up the serene surroundings. Things to see in GambiaFrom historic landmarks to hidden gems, Gambia offers a range of sights that capture its culture, history, and natural beauty. Arch 22 is an iconic arch that commemorates the 1994 coup and offers panoramic views over Banjul and the Gambia River. It stands 36 metres high so climb to the top for the incredible photo-worthy views and with a cafe and museum here too, you can appreciate Gambian history with a nice treat. The Bakau Botanical Gardens offers a peaceful oasis perfect for a romantic stroll. The gardens are brimming with tropical plants, palm trees, and serene pathways giving you an escape from the bustling towns. Itâ€™s ideal for families or nature lovers, or if youâ€™re looking for an afternoon out of the beaming sun. To explore more of Gambia, head to Tanji, particularly the Tanji Village Museum. Itâ€™s a small but fascinating museum showing Gambian fishing culture and history, with traditional boats, tools and exhibits on local life. Nightlife in GambiaGambiaâ€™s nightlife is lively but relaxed â€“ the ultimate combo. With options ranging from beach bars and live music venues to bustling clubs and local cultural evenings, you can expect a bit of everything. Nightlife in Bijilo is low-key, with a handful of beach bars and small restaurants offering live music and cocktails. Itâ€™s the perfect place for couples or friends looking for a relaxed evening with ocean views. Cape Point is also a quieter, scenic area with intimate nightlife. Expect sunset dinners followed by a few drinks and a peaceful atmosphere. Kololi is the heart of Gambiaâ€™s party scene. The Senegambia Strip comes alive at night with bars, nightclubs, and live entertainment, ideal for younger party crowds or anyone seeking energetic nightlife, cocktails and music until late. Kotu Beach offers a good mix of casual beach bars and lively venues, with live music and friendly atmospheres. Itâ€™s a great pick for families and friends wanting a lively night out without the bustle of Kololi. Gambian cuisineGambian cuisine is a hearty and flavourful mix of West African, Portuguese, and French influences, shaped by the countryâ€™s rivers, fertile land and coastal access. Expect a huge focus on dishes with rice, seafood, plantain and aromas of garlic, onions and tomato. Domoda is a rich peanut butter stew made with meat, fish, or chicken and vegetables, usually served with rice. Considered as Gambiaâ€™s national dish, itâ€™s a must try for anyone wanting an authentic taste of local flavours. Street food in Gambia is popular for affordable lunches and snacks, like fish rolls â€“ fried fish in soft bread â€“ fataya â€“ deep-fried pastry pockets filled with spiced meat or fish â€“ and even kebabs, with grilled beef, chicken or seafood. Desserts in Gambia are often simple and sweet with a focus on local ingredients like peanuts and tropical fruits including mango, papaya and pineapple. You can expect to find sweet treats in my food stalls and local cafes, perfect for an afternoon snack or after your evening meal. Drinks in GambiaGambia has a variety of traditional drinks that reflect its culture, climate and local ingredients, perfect for refreshing yourself while basking in the beaming sunshine. Baobab Juice is a tangy, vitamin-rich drink made from baobab fruit pulp and often served chilled. It pairs well with grilled fish, fried snacks or light meals for a refreshing balance. The perfect accompaniment for your spicy evening meal, Bissap is a sweetened hibiscus flower drink â€“ sometimes flavored with mint or ginger, it perfectly compliments the bold flavours of your meal. Attaya is a Gambian Tea â€“ a strong green tea brewed with sugar and traditionally enjoyed with biscuits, cakes or peanut-based sweets. Perfecting attaya is a long process involving pouring the tea from a height, several times and between cups, to create three different strength teapots. Palm Wine is a mildly alcoholic, lightly sweet drink tapped from palm trees and itâ€™s a great compliment to any seafood or meat dish. Costs in GambiaPrices in Gambia can vary depending on where you are, but here are some typical average costs: A three-course meal for two at a mid-range restaurant can cost around Â£35â€“Â£55. Food from street vendors is much cheaper, usually less than a few pounds. A bottle of local beer might cost around Â£1.40, a soft drink about Â£1.10, a glass of wine Â£4â€“Â£5, and cocktails in the more upscale bars Â£6â€“Â£8. A short taxi ride of about 5 km during the day would typically cost around Â£4.50. How much could some typical excursions in Gambia cost me? Head on a half day tour around Gambiaâ€™s capital, Banjul, exploring the sights and history for around Â£50 per adult and Â£20 per child. Enjoy an evening preparing and eating an evening meal with a local family in their home, for around Â£30 per person. Frequently asked questions about holidays to GambiaWhat is the best time to go to Gambia?Make the most of the countryâ€™s amazing, stunning beaches during the dry season and enjoy average temperatures of around 24 degrees celsius across the coastal areas. Whatever time of the year you choose for your holiday to Gambia, you can rest easy knowing that you will experience tropical temperatures with sunshine all around you. Is Gambia expensive?Look to book an all inclusive holiday Gambia and everything will be included in your price from drinks and food to flights, hotels and transfers. Local supermarkets offer you the chance to pick up little bits such as snacks and any essentials you may have forgotten, all at relatively cheap prices too. Does Gambia have beaches?It certainly does and theyâ€™re often quiet, serene places where you can unwind and relax in the sunshine. Along the coastal areas youâ€™ll find beautiful sandy beaches that are just waiting for you to explore them. With an amazing climate, friendly locals and so much wildlife on offer throughout the country, you can either choose to relax by the sea or explore inland some more. Why is Gambia popular with tourists?As there is so much to do in The Gambia, there is never a dull moment. Thereâ€™s so many activities to dive into as well as the beautiful surroundings you will find yourself in. Many tourists love the diverse wildlife on offer and with the opportunity to see this first hand you can rest assured your holiday is going to be memorable. What are the hottest months in Gambia?Around May time are the hottest parts of the year when it comes to a holiday to The Gambia. As you head out of the dry season and into the wet season you can experience higher temperatures such as in August but you run the risk of rain, although it can be quite refreshing during soaring temperatures! What is the currency in Gambia?The currency in Gambia is the Gambian Dalasi (GMD). This is a closed currency which means you can only buy and sell your travel money once youâ€™re in the country, and before you leave again. What language do they speak in Gambia?The most common spoken language in Gambia is English, although you are likely to hear many tribal languages, like Mandinka and Wolof. What is the time difference between the UK and Gambia?Gambia shares the same timezone as the UK, GMT +0, so there is no time difference. How long is the flight from the UK to Gambia?The average flight time from the UK (London) to Gambia is 5 hours 30 minutes. This can vary depending on where youâ€™re flying from. Do I need a visa to travel to Gambia?For holidays up to 28 days in Gambia you do not need a visa. For holidays longer than 28 days,you can get an extension â€“ find out more information.

scraped_itos.content: The Gambia tours & holidaysThe smallest country in continental Africa leaves a big, big impressionAlthough petite in size, The Gambia is a powerhouse of biodiversity. With an abundance of different ecosystems and nature reserves, you don't have to travel far to see some amazing wildlife. Although this part of West Africa is a birdwatchers' paradise with over 600 species of birds, you'll also want to be on the lookout for Nile crocodiles, hippos, spitting cobras and monkeys. Your camera is a non-negotiable for a trip to the Gambia.Our The Gambia trips Refine search Senegal & The Gambia Adventure 12 days Original From GBP Â£2,376Build your dream adventure Let's create an exclusive trip for your group. Explore tailor-made trips Get inspired on The Good Times Read all stories Guides5 West African countries that should be on your radarThe Goods 2025: New trips & experiences7 new ways to make a difference as you travel with Intrepid The Goods 2025: New trips & experiences12 new ways to get closer to nature with Intrepid The Goods 2025: New trips & experiences8 of the best traditional foods to try in West Africa The Goods 2025: New trips & experiences9 new experiences for beach lovers and island hoppers Read all stories We also travel toTogoSenegalBeninGhanaThe Gambia at a glance CAPITAL CITYBanjul (population 480,000)POPULATION2.7 millionCURRENCYGMDLANGUAGEEnglish (official), Wolof, Mandinka, FulaTIME ZONE(GMT) CasablancaCALLING CODE+220ELECTRICITYType G (Irish/British 3-pin) Type C (European 2-pin) Learn more about The GambiaBest time to visit The GambiaBest time to visit The GambiaThe best time to visit Gambia is from November to February when temperatures are pleasant, and thereâ€™s little humidity. Conveniently, this is also the best time to spot birds and wildlife as the country is green and lush.The average temperature rises between mid-February and April, and humidity can be oppressive. Intense periods of rain have been known to wash away some of the roads.Geography and environmentGeography and environmentCompletely surrounded by Senegal save for its 80-kilometre stretch of coastline, the Gambia is an exceptionally flat country. The highest point is only 53 metres above sea level. The countryâ€™s namesake river begins in the east and travels among tropical rainforests before gradually giving way to mangrove swamps and coastlines. Further from the river, savannahs and plantation woodlands dot the landscape.Top 5 Gambian drinksTop 5 Gambian drinks1. BissapBlood-red and extremely sweet, bissap (or manjo) is an infused herbal tea made from the flowers of the hibiscus plant, and itâ€™s the nationâ€™s number one drink. Typically flavoured with ginger or mint, it makes for a refreshing midday beverage. And with preliminary studies recently suggesting that it may reduce blood pressure, you may well return home in better shape than you left.2. AtaayaAs much a social rite as a no-holds-barred caffeine injection, try the three-glass Ataaya ceremony when youâ€™re looking to recharge the batteries or make some local friends. One part Chinese green tea leaves to two parts sugar, three parts water and a bunch of mint â€“ think of it as the teetotallerâ€™s mojito.3. KinkelibaBrewed from the leaves of the local Kinkeliba plant, this strong, sweet herbal tea is mostly drunk as a breakfast tonic or at dusk during Ramadan when its appetite-stimulant qualities assist in gorging on the evening meal.4. BouyiA thick, syrupy juice made from the fruit of the baobab, this ultra-sweet libation imparts an unmatched sugar high and is certainly more appetising than its ungainly tree would have you expect.5. JulBrewDescribed by some beer buffs as evoking aromas of hay, boiled vegetables, canned corn and cardboard, Gambiaâ€™s national beer is probably unlikely to scoop any international beer awards. But knocked back on a white sandy beach while being buffed by delightful sea breezes, youâ€™re hardly likely to care.The Gambia travel FAQsDo I need a visa to travel to The Gambia?Most nationalities will need to obtain a visa in advance to travel to The Gambia.Visas are the responsibility of the individual traveller. Entry requirements can change at any time, so it's important that you check for the latest information.You can check the entry requirements for your nationality on your government's foreign travel advisories, consular websites or on our visa and entry requirements page.Do I need to purchase travel insurance before travelling?Absolutely. All passengers travelling with Intrepid are required to purchase travel insurance before the start of their trip. It's important to understand that each country you visit may have its own specific entry requirements, and some destinations mandate travel health insurance for all foreign travellers, regardless of their nationality.Your leader will record your travel insurance details on the first day of the trip. Due to the varying nature, availability and cost of health care around the world, travel insurance is an essential part of every journey.Read more about travel insuranceIs tipping customary in The Gambia?A 10% service charge is usually added to the bill in established restaurants, bars, hotels and taxis â€” but feel free to tip more than this for exceptional service. At restaurants where a service charge isnâ€™t included, 10% is the acceptable gratuity. Although tipping at other places isn't mandatory it will be much appreciated given the low wages that Gambian service workers are typically paid. Setting aside a small amount for porters, guides and drivers is also a good idea.Can I drink the water in The Gambia?Tap water isn't safe to drink in The Gambia. Hotels and lodges will often provide filtered water, and your local leader is always available to help. Water filtration tablets are often helpful for peace of mind.What is the internet access like in The Gambia?The internet connection can be a little slow in some remote areas, especially in towns further inland. Hotels, cafes and bars in Banjul usually have wi-fi with reliable connectivity.Can I use my mobile phone while in The Gambia?Mobile phone coverage is good in The Gambiaâ€™s large cities and towns but less so in rural areas. If you plan to use your mobile phone, ensure you have global roaming activated or download an eSIM before leaving home.What is ATM access like in The Gambia?ATMs can be found at banks in urban areas like Banjul and Serrekunda, though they arenâ€™t always reliable. Due to credit card and bank fraud, caution is advised when using these, and some ATMs may only allow withdrawals of fairly small amounts.Are credit cards accepted in The Gambia?The Gambia is primarily a cash-based economy. Credit cards are generally only accepted at top-end hotels and at some high-end restaurants in Banjul. We recommend you carry enough local currency on your trip.What are the toilets like in The Gambia?Fairly clean western-style toilets can generally be found in Banjul and the towns on the Atlantic Coast. In towns and villages further inland, squat/pit toilets are the norm. Carry your own supply of soap and toilet paper, as this is rarely provided.How do I stay safe and healthy while travelling?We take the health and safety of our travellers seriously and take every measure to ensure that trips are safe, fun and inclusive for everyone. When you travel with us, you have access to our global support network and local onâ€‘ground leadership, and you can rest easy knowing we have a zero-tolerance policy on discrimination.We recommend that all travellers check with their government or national travel advisory organisation for the latest information before departure. The World Health Organisation also provides useful health information.Travelling from Australia?Go to: Smart TravellerFrom Canada?Go to: Canada Travel InformationFrom the UK?Go to: UK Foreign Travel AdviceFrom New Zealand?Go to: Safe TravelFrom the US?Go to: US Department of StateLearn more about safe travels with IntrepidSMALL GROUP TRAVEL THAT'S GOOD ALL OVERWe're here to do good by creating positive change through the joy of travel.We're here to do good by creating positive change through the joy of travel.Our purposeOur purpose

Water babies can enjoy kayaking while foodies wonâ€™t want to miss the sights and tastes of Gambian markets.Explore Kunta Kinteh Island: Take a boat trip to this UNESCO World Heritage Site (and ancestral home of the fictional character, Kunta Kinte, from the novel Roots). Learn about the island's dark history as a former slave trading post and see the ruins of the old fort.Discover Bijilo Forest Park: Wander through this lush coastal forest reserve, home to troops of vervet and red colobus monkeys. Keep an eye out for monitor lizards, over 100 bird species and the park's towering silk cotton trees â€“ some over 200 years old!Relax on Sanyang Beach: Escape the crowds at this pristine stretch of golden sand fringed by coconut palms. Take a dip in the warm Atlantic waters, watch the fishermen bring in their catch or simply soak up the laid-back vibes of this unspoiled coastal gem.Visit Wassu Stone Circles: Marvel at these ancient megalithic structures dating back to 500-1000 AD. The purpose of the stone circles remains a mystery, but they offer a fascinating glimpse into Gambia's pre-colonial past. The site also has an informative visitor centre.Experience Serekunda Market: Immerse yourself in the sights, sounds and smells of Gambia's largest market. Haggle for fresh produce, colourful textiles and handcrafted souvenirs or simply soak up the vibrant atmosphere. Be sure to try the delicious street food, from grilled fish to spicy domoda stew.Gambia beachesThe Gambia has an 80km-long coastline, making it perfect for beach holidays. Pack your swimsuit for our top choices:Kololi Beach: Golden sands and crystal-clear waters make Kololi a popular choice. Lined with beach bars, restaurants and hotels, it's a lively spot to soak up the sun, try water sports or enjoy a sundowner. The beach is well-maintained and safe for swimming.Kotu Beach: Just south of Kololi, Kotu offers a more chilled-out vibe. This wide, sandy beach is fringed by palm trees and has fewer crowds. It's a great spot for a quiet stroll or to watch the fishermen bring in their catch.Sanyang Beach: Escape the resorts at this unspoiled stretch of coast. Sanyang feels a world away, with its deserted sands, sleepy village and cool beach bars. It's a popular spot for surfing and fishing, with a relaxed, hippie vibe.Bijilo Beach: Backed by the Bijilo Forest Park, this secluded beach offers golden sands and plenty of shade. It's a quiet alternative to the main resort beaches, popular with locals and visitors looking to kick back. The nearby forest is home to monkeys and birdlife.Brufut Beach: Wide, golden shores stretch for miles at Brufut, one of Gambia's most stunning beaches. It's a great place for a long walk, with a handful of local beach bars to stop at along the way. The sunsets here are particularly spectacular.We loveFood of GambiaGambian cuisine is a delicious fusion of African, Middle Eastern and European influences. From hearty one-pot dishes like benachin and domoda to tangy yassa and nourishing superkanja, the flavours of Gambia are sure tempt any foodie.Benachin: This 1-pot rice dish is a staple in Gambian cuisine. Cooked with fish or meat, vegetables and tomato paste, it's a hearty meal bursting with flavour. Head to the beach bars of Kololi for some of the best benachin around.Domoda: A deliciously rich groundnut stew, domoda is made with beef, chicken or fish simmered in a sauce of peanut butter, tomatoes and spices. Serekunda Market is the place to go for an authentic taste of this national dish.Yassa: Yassa is a tangy chicken or fish dish marinated in lemon juice, onions and mustard. Grilled over an open fire, it's a smoky and zesty taste sensation. Try it at the roadside stalls near Banjul's Albert Market.Afra: These fluffy deep-fried dough balls are a popular breakfast food or snack. Served with a spicy dipping sauce, they're the perfect pick-me-up at any time of day. Grab a bag from the vendors at Bakau Craft Market.Superkanja: This nourishing okra stew is packed with beef, fish and vegetables in a thick, green sauce. It's a comforting and healthy dish that's popular across the country. For a top-notch superkanja, try the local restaurants around Serrekunda.Adventure holidays in The GambiaGambia offers thrilling adventures for adrenaline lovers. Trek through jungles to spot chimpanzees, kayak in serene wetlands, go off-road cycling in national parks, abseil down sea cliffs or try deep-sea fishing for barracuda!Chimpanzee Trekking in River Gambia National Park: Embark on an unforgettable adventure into the heart of the jungle to spot our closest living relatives in their natural habitat. Led by expert guides, youâ€™ll trek through lush rainforest and observe the playful antics of these fascinating primates up close.Kayaking through the Tanbi Wetlands: Paddle your way through a labyrinth of mangroves, spotting rare birds and wildlife as you go. This tranquil network of creeks and lagoons is a hidden treasure, offering a unique look at Gambiaâ€™s beauty.Off-road Cycling in Niumi National Park: Get off-the-beaten-track on an exhilarating bike ride through rugged terrain. Navigate dirt tracks and forest trails, passing remote villages and sweeping coastal vistas. With plenty of opportunities for animal sightings along the way, it's a thrilling way to explore.Abseiling down Baboon Cliffs: Test your nerve with a heart-pumping abseil down these towering sea cliffs. Under the guidance of experienced instructors, you'll descend 50m to the beach below, enjoying breathtaking views of the Atlantic.Deep Sea Fishing off the coast of Tanji: Set sail on a traditional pirogue for an unforgettable day of fishing on the open ocean. With local fishermen as your guides, you'll have the chance to catch barracuda, grouper and snapper, and maybe even see dolphins and whales from the boat.Holiday typesFamily holidays to The GambiaWith its warm hospitality, delicious cuisine and wealth of child-friendly activities, this small West African nation promises an unforgettable adventure for all ages. Be sure to check out our family-friendly favourites:Tanji Village Museum: Step back in time at this open-air museum showcasing traditional Gambian life. Kids will love exploring the replica compounds, trying their hand at crafts like tie-dyeing and weaving, and learning about local customs from friendly guides.Makasutu Culture Forest: Embark on a pirogue ride through the mangroves of this lush reserve. Spot monkeys, monitor lizards and colourful birds along the way, then visit the cultural centre to see traditional dance performances and wood-carving demonstrations.Tanji Fishing Village: Watch the colourful pirogues bring in their catch and see the women processing the fish at this energetic coastal village. Kids can help carry the baskets of fish and learn about the importance of fishing to the community.Brikama Craft Market: Wander through the stalls of this vibrant market, where artisans create beautiful textiles, wood carvings and pottery. Children can try their hand at batik printing or drumming, and pick up some unique souvenirs to take home.Bakau Botanical Gardens: Let the kids run wild in these tranquil gardens, home to towering silk cotton trees, chattering birds and butterflies. Pack a picnic and enjoy a leisurely lunch on the lawns, or take a guided tour to learn about the flora and fauna.Couples holidays to The GambiaThe Gambia offers a whole new world of romantic escape for couples. From private river cruises to secluded beach picnics, there are plenty of opportunities to spend quality time together in this tropical paradise.Sunset Cruise on the River Gambia: Sip champagne and watch the sun dip below the horizon on a romantic river cruise. Spot birds and wildlife along the banks as you glide past mangroves and fishing villages. The tranquil waters and stunning scenery make for an intimate-feeling experience.Couples Spa Day at Coco Ocean Resort: Unwind with a side-by-side massage, followed by a dip in the infinity pool overlooking the ocean at this luxurious beachfront resort. The serene atmosphere and attentive service will leave you feeling refreshed and reconnected.Private Beach Picnic at Tujering: Escape the crowds with a secluded beach picnic. Your private guide will lead you to a hidden cove where you can swim, sunbathe and enjoy a gourmet lunch. It's the perfect way to spend quality time together in a stunning setting.Sunset Horseback Ride at Fajara: Canter along the beach at sunset on a guided horseback ride. No experience is necessary, and the gentle horses are well-suited for beginners. As the sky turns pink and orange, you'll create magical memories together.Cooking Class at Yabouy Home Cooking: Learn the secrets of Gambian cuisine with a private cooking class for couples. Shop for ingredients at the local market, then prepare authentic dishes like benachin and domoda under the guidance of a skilled chef. Savour your creations together in a candlelit garden setting.Your Gambia questions answeredWhere is The Gambia?Is The Gambia a good holiday destination?When is the best time to visit The Gambia?Where is The Gambia?The Gambia is a small country located in West Africa. Itâ€™s the smallest country on the African mainland and is surrounded by Senegal on all sides except for a short coastline on the Atlantic Ocean.The Gambia is situated on the banks of the River Gambia, which flows through the centre of the country.Is The Gambia a good holiday destination?Yes, The Gambia is an excellent holiday destination, especially if youâ€™re seeking a unique and memorable experience in West Africa.Known for its stunning Atlantic coastline, the nation boasts pristine beaches perfect for sunbathing and water sports. Wildlife enthusiasts will appreciate the diverse birdlife and opportunities for river safaris along the Gambia River, and the warm, welcoming locals and their rich culture add depth to any visit. While luxury resorts are available, budget-friendly options are on the cards too.When is the best time to visit The Gambia?The dry season, which runs from October to June, are the best months to visit The Gambia, as youâ€™ll experience great temperatures and low levels of humidity.Gambia weatherJan30Â°CAvg. scraped_itos.title: Destinations - Gambia - Luxotour
scraped_itos.content: Luxotour/Africa/Gambia GambiaOfficially the Islamic Republic of the Gambia, it is a nation in West Africa. It is completely surrounded by Senegal, except at the mouth of the Gambia River into the Atlantic Ocean. Its capital is Banjul, although the largest city in the country is Serekunda. The country is located on the banks of the Gambia River, which gives its name to the country, and which runs through its center and empties into the Atlantic Ocean. The country has an area of 10,500 kmÂ² and an estimated population of 1.7 million people. The Gambia shares with the rest of the nations of West Africa a past associated with the slave market, which It was the key factor for the location and maintenance of a colony on the Gambia River, first maintained by the Portuguese and later by the British Empire. On February 18, 1965, The Gambia achieved independence from the United Kingdom and since then the country has enjoyed relative political stability, with the exception of a short period of military dictatorship in 1994.It is a country with very fertile lands that have turned agriculture into one of the key elements of its economy, along with fishing and tourism.Programs at GambiaSindola and South GambiaBased on 2 or 3 passengers traveling together.7 nightsWhat to see in Gambia?Makasutu ForestIn the west of the country, there is the Makasutu Cultural Forest, which stands out for its natural variety and the living culture found there.Makasutu Park is a lush green space where you can find various types of nature such as mangroves, a mature and dense tropical forest, typical Guinean forests, savanna and grasslands. The reserve is open to the public for cultural and tourist tours during the day, which has made it one of the greatest local attractions.On a day tour of this park it is possible to enjoy various cultural displays such as traditional dances of the Jola tribe, some singing accompanied by drums and a traditional Gambian meal at the local restaurant. It is also possible to take canoe tours through the mangroves, as well as learn about traditional herbal remedies and even go bird watching on the salt flats along the river.Kiang National ParkKiang West National Park is one of the largest and most important wildlife reserves in The Gambia. It was declared a National Park in 1987 and is managed by the Gambia Department of Parks and Wildlife Management.The park covers an area of 11,526 hectares and is located on the south bank of the Gambia River, in the Lower River division in Kiang West district. The park headquarters is located in Dumbuto Village, an 18-minute drive from Tendaba Village. The Gambia River marks the northern boundary of the park. Three bolons (streams), Jarin, Jali and Nganingkoi, divide the interior of the park into three sections. The park is unpopulated and there are towns located near its boundaries. Most of the park is located on a low-altitude plateau and is mainly Guinea savannah and dry deciduous forests, and also has salt marshes and mangrove streams.Vegetation types in the park include savanna. Guineana and the dry deciduous forest. Tree species in the park include the baobab, red acacia, Pterocarpus erinaceus, Ceiba pentandra, Terminalia macroptera, Prosopis Africana and Ficus species. The park is an important area for Gambian wildlife, as it is home to individuals of most of the remaining mammal species. These mammals include the African clawless otter, antelope, caracal, common duiker, leopard, swamp mongoose, serval, sitatunga, spotted hyena, wild boars and West African manatee. Reptile species in the park include the African python, Bell's hinged turtle, West African crocodile, Nile monitor (Varanus niloticus), viper, royal python and spitting cobra. The park has more than 300 species of birds, more than half of all bird species recorded in The Gambia. Some of the bird species in the park have a very local distribution and are rarely seen elsewhere in The Gambia. There are 21 birds of prey, including species of eagle, falcon, harrier, falcon and vulture. Other bird species in the park include ten species of kingfisher, the ground hornbill and the endangered brown-necked parrot, which breeds in the park's mangroves.SanyangThe tranquil Sanyang Beach, like the coastal area of the Atlantic Ocean that surrounds it, is called by locals simply Sanyang. The stretch of beach is located in the West Coast region in the Kombo South district.WassuWassu is a community in the interior of the Gambia, owner of Janjang-bureh. The Senegambia Megalithic Circles or Senegambia Stone Circles are located in the Central River Division of the Gambia and the Kaolack Region of Senegal. They consist of four large groups of megalithic circles, formed by stone cylinders, which represent an extraordinary concentration of 1000 monuments. The four groups, Sine NgayÃ¨ne, Wanar, Wassu and Kerbatch all together add up to 93 stone circles. They cover an area of 9.85 hectares and a protected area of 110.05 hectares.Kunkilling Nature ParkKunkilling Forest Park is a forest park in The Gambia. Established on January 1, 1954, it covers 142 hectares. The forest park is located in a village called Kerr Serrekunda on the southern bank of the Gambia River.prevnextUseful information for traveling to GambiaEntry formalitiesNo visa required. Visitors of Spanish nationality only need to have a valid passport with a minimum validity of six months.LanguageEnglish was the official language of The Gambia until 2014, since then the official language has been Arabic. Although several regional languages are also spoken such as Mandika, Wolof, Fula, Serer in addition to Creole Krio. Due to the regional location, there is a good knowledge of French, which is official in much of West and Central Africa, and is widely spoken in countries in the region.CurrencyThe official currency is the dalasi (GMD), which is divided into 100 bututs. You can exchange currency at the airport and at banks and exchange offices in cities. Traveler's checks issued in euros, US dollars or British pounds can be exchanged upon payment of a fee. MasterCard, American Express and Visa credit cards are accepted in most hotels. Bank hours: Monday to Thursday from 8:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m., Fridays from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. Certain banks are open on Saturday mornings.Electricity220V. Plugs are round or square, with three pins. No adapter required.Health preventionsThe yellow fever vaccine is mandatory. Other recommended vaccines: diphtheria, tetanus, poliomyelitis, typhus, hepatitis A and B. It is recommended to follow antimalarial treatment since the country is classified in zone 3. Drink only bottled water. Do not consume raw foods (meat, fish, vegetables, fruits...).ClimateIts climate is tropical, with the months from June to November being the hottest and rainiest and from December to May having cooler and drier weather. Temperatures on the coast are moderate, but they increase inland, becoming very warm in the eastern part of the country.GastronomyTraditional dishes of Gambian cuisine are mostly made from rice (the staple food), with various spicy sauces. However, steamed millet, couscous or cassava are also common.The ingredients that define these dishes are peanut butter (Domoda), okra (okra), palm oil (chew deu terr) or edible leaves such as spinach or cassava leaves. Very popular among poor families is Mbahal, which is rice mixed with grated peanuts and dried fish. Some of the best known typical dishes are Domoda (sauce of peanut butter), supakanja (okra stew), benachin (jolof rice), chere (millet couscous) or chicken yassa (fried chicken in onion).Diferencia horaria con EspaÃ±aLa diferencia horaria con EspaÃ±a es de -1 hora en invierno y -2 horas en verano.PopulationIt has 1.7 million inhabitants and various ethnic groups such as the Mandingas (41%), the Peuls, the Wolofs, the Soninkes, the Diolas and the Akus.
